name: Graviera Naxou
fun: Graviera Naxou was inspired by the Swiss Gruyère
content: Cow's milk (at least 80%) with addition of sheep and goat's milk (up to 20%)

name: Parmigiano Reggiano
fun: Parmigiano Reggiano is officially considered a 'space food', chosen by both NASA and Russian space programs for astronaut diets
content: 100% natural, raw, cow's milk cheese

name: Queijo de Azeitão
fun: Queijo de Azeitão is a rare, 100% vegetarian, creamy sheep's milk cheese
content: Unpasteurized sheep's milk

name: Mozzarella di Bufala Campana
fun: Mozzarella di Bufala Campana DOP is protected by European law, meaning it can only be made in specific areas of southern Italy
content: made from the milk of the Italian Mediterranean buffalo

name: Graviera Kritis
fun: The cheese matures for 3 to 5 months before going to market
content: Up to 20 percent goat's milk mixed with sheep's milk, and it must all come from free-range animals

name: Queijo Serra da Estrela
fun: The Serra da Estrela cheese is a recipe handed down through generations
content: Milk of Bordaleira Serra da Estrela and Churra Mondegueira breeds of sheep

name: Pecorino Sardo
fun: The name does not derive from the capital but from history: it was the ideal food for the sustenance of the Roman army
content: 100% whole sheep's milk

name: Kefalograviera
fun: It seems to be a relatively recent innovation, the submission document from 1996 said it had only come into production “over recent decades”
content: Made with cow, goat, and sheep milk that is typically pasteurized

name: Burrata
fun: Burrata is as white as mozzarella but comes with a strange narrowing at the top, like a giant dumpling
content: Italian cow's milk (occasionally buffalo milk) that is typically pasteurized or unpasteurized

name: Saint-Félicien
fun: It is the invention of an 80-year-old creamery just south of Lyon
content: Raw or pasteurized cow's milk

name: Metsovone
fun: Metsovone may be made in a similar way to a smoked provolone, but the two cheeses have different tastes due to distinct cheesemaking processes
content: Made with cow, goat, or sheep milk that is typically unpasteurized

name: Pecorino Toscano
fun: Pecorino Romano is one of the few cheeses in the world that boasts a thousand-year history
content: 100% whole sheep’s milk

name: Saint-André
fun: Saint-André is a notoriously rich French 'triple cream' cheese with a 75% butterfat content, making it closer to butter than typical Brie
content: Made with cow milk that is typically raw

name: Pecorino Siciliano
fun: Pecorino Siciliano, one of Europe's oldest cheeses with roots in ancient Greece, is famously mentioned in Homer's Odyssey (written around the 8th Century BC)
content: raw, whole sheep's milk (ewe's milk) sourced from animals raised in Sicily

name: Redykołka
fun: It is made from the leftover curds of the larger oscypek, and it is traditionally molded into intricate, decorative shapes like animals, birds, or hearts
content: Primarily made from unpasteurized sheep's milk in the Podhale region, may include up to 40% cow's milk from the Polish Red Cow breed.

name: Livanjski sir
fun: Livanjski sir was first produced in 1886
content: Sheep's milk, or mixture of sheep's and cow's milk

name: Brillat-Savarin
fun: Brillat-Savarin is a decadent 'triple cream' French cheese with over 75% fat content, often called the 'foie gras' of cheeses
content: Made with good cow's milk

name: Canastra
fun: It was the first Brazilian cheese to win an international award in France (2015)
content: cow's milk (unpasteurized)

name: Gołka
fun: It is often produced in cylindrical, 'log' shapes rather than the classic spindle-shaped mold used for traditional highland cheese
content: 100% goat's milk

name: Mont d'Or
fun: It's one of only a few French cheeses you have to eat with a spoon!
content: Unpasteurized cow's milk

name: Kalathaki Limnou
fun: It is actually drained and aged inside tiny, traditional wicker baskets (giving it a basket-weave, ridged pattern) before being submerged in brine, with the name literally translating to 'little basket'
content: Pasteurized sheep's milk or a mix of sheep's and up to 30% goat's milk

name: Grana Padano
fun: It is naturally lactose-free
content: Raw milk, which makes up 98%

name: Pecorino Romano
fun: A cheese made from sheep's milk that was a staple food for the Roman army
content: 100% pasteurized or raw Italian sheep's milk

name: Anthotyro
fun: The name anthotyro means flowery cheese, referring to the strong aromas of wild herbs
content: From goat's or sheep's milk

name: Burrata di Andria
fun: It was created as a way to avoid waste by stuffing leftover mozzarella scraps and cream inside a fresh mozzarella shell
content: Italian cow's milk

name: Queijo Serpa
fun: Serpa is the most famous traditional Alentejano, region of Portugal, cheese
content: Raw sheep milk

name: San Michali
fun: This hard cheese has a cylindrical shape, a compact texture, and a distinct salty and peppery flavor
content: pasteurized or sometimes partly skimmed cow's milk

name: Beaufort
fun: It has a unique concave (inward-curving) rind specifically designed to act as a 'dairy pulley' for transporting heavy, 70kg wheels on donkey backs down steep Alps
content: Raw cow's milk

name: West Country Farmhouse Cheddar
fun: This cheddar was historically matured in the caves of Cheddar Gorge, which provided the perfect, cool, and humid environment for aging
content: Pasteurised cow's milk

name: Queijo de Cabra Transmontano
fun: It is often aged for up to two years to become a 'Velho' (old) cheese, turning it from a semi-hard, mild cheese into a firm, intense, and spicy delicacy
content: Raw milk from the Cabra Serrana goat breed

name: Ladotyri Mytilinis
fun: It was historically matured and stored in olive oil to preserve it before modern refrigeration
content: 100% sheep's milk or a mixture containing at least 70% sheep's milk and a maximum of 30% goat’s milk

name: Comté
fun: It boasts up to 83 distinct flavors, changing from summer (yellow) to winter (ivory)
content: Only milk from Montbéliarde or French Simmental cows (or cross breeds of the two)

name: Tenili
fun: Made from sheep or cow milk
content: It is incredibly labor-intensive to produce, serving Tenili is considered a sign of high honor and respect for a guest

name: Sfela
fun: Sfela is called 'fire cheese' because the curd is reheated during production
content: Made from sheep's milk or a mix of sheep and goat milk

name: Arseniko Naxou
fun: 'Arseniko' means male in Greek, referring to its sharp, aggressive, and strong character, as it is made using the most robust part of the morning milk. It is often paired with Thylikatori (female), a soft cheese made from the leftover whey of the Arseniko
content: Unpasteurized local sheep and goats' milk

name: Ovčí Salašnícky Údený Syr
fun: It is still often produced by hand using traditional methods and sometimes shaped with wooden molds, giving it a unique rustic, smoky profile
content: Unpasteurized sheep's milk

name: Stracciata
fun: Originally created to prevent waste by mixing leftover, hand-torn mozzarella shreds with heavy cream
content: Produced from Italian buffalo milk

name: Graviera Agrafon
fun: It is actually more popular outside of Greece—specifically in France, Switzerland, and Germany—than within its home country
content: Raw sheep's milk with up to 30 percent goat's milk

name: Mastelo
fun: It has an incredible, high melting point, allowing it to be grilled or pan-fried without losing its shape or melting away
content: From rich Chian cow's milk

name: Manchego viejo
fun: The wheel shape of cheese is due to the fact that it was originally produced in a round form to make transportation easier
content: 100% whole milk of the Manchega sheep

name: Manchego curado
fun: The zigzag, herringbone pattern on the rind is not just decorative; it historically mimics the woven grass molds (esparto) used to drain the cheese
content: 100% whole milk of the Manchega sheep

name: Crottin de Chavignol
fun: It was originally named after the clay oil lamps (crot) used in local wine cellars, not animal waste
content: Raw, whole goat's milk in the Loire Valley

name: Noord-Hollandse Gouda
fun: While it is world-famous, Gouda is named after the town where it was historically traded, not necessarily produced
content: Pasteurized cow's milk

name: Idiazabal
fun: While it is a hard cheese, it has a surprisingly oily and elastic texture when eaten
content: 100% raw, whole milk, exclusively from Latxa or Carranzana sheep

name: Ricotta di Bufala Campana
fun: It is not technically a 'cheese but rather a dairy byproduct, or latticino, made by 're-cooking' the leftover whey from Mozzarella di Bufala
content: Whey of buffalo milk in the Campania region of Italy

name: Xynomyzithra Kritis
fun: It is a Greek cheese that is actually a 'recycling' product, traditionally made from the leftover whey of harder cheeses like Graviera
content: Whey of sheep's or goat's milk, with added milk and cream

name: Mozzarella
fun: Mozzarella's name comes from the Neapolitan dialect word mozzare ('to cut off'), describing how the curd is hand-stretched and cut into individual balls, a technique developed to create its signature texture
content: Water buffalo or cow's milk

name: Gorgonzola dolce
fun: Legend says a distracted cheesemaker in a hurry to meet his lover forgot his curds, resulting in an accidental, delightful, and creamy mold-veined cheese
content: Cow milk that is typically pasteurized

name: Queijo de Coalho
fun: Despite being heated directly over fire, Coalho does not turn into a puddle; it becomes golden and soft inside, making it an ideal, non-leaking, high-temperature grilling cheese
content: Cow's milk, it can be crafted using either pasteurized or unpasteurized milk

name: Gorgonzola piccante
fun: A robust, aged Italian blue cheese, is deeply connected to a legend of a 'lovesick cheesemaker' who was so distracted by a romantic rendezvous that he left his curds in a cauldron overnight, accidentally inventing the crumbly, spicy, and mold-veined cheese (also known as erborinatura) through this mistake
content: Pasteurized or raw whole cow’s milk

name: Ciliegine mozzarella
fun: Ciliegine meaning 'cherry' in Italian, refers to small, cherry-sized mozzarella balls
content: Pasteurized cow's milk

name: Katiki Domokou
fun: Unlike most cheeses, Katiki Domokou curdles primarily through acidic fermentation (often using natural yogurt or sour milk), not rennet
content: Pasteurized goat and sheep milk (or a mix)

name: Provolone del Monaco
fun: It is often shaped like a melon or pear, with distinct grooves from the cords used to hang it while it cures for 4 to 18 months
content: Raw whole cow's milk, at least 20 percent of which comes from the local Agerolese breed

name: Bryndza Podhalańska
fun: Traditionally, in the region, this cheese has been considered so healthy due to its high protein, calcium, and vitamin (A, B, D) content that it is nicknamed 'white gold'
content: Unpasteurized sheep's milk

name: Oaxaca cheese
fun: The legend states that a young girl accidentally let the milk for her cheese curds coagulate too much. To hide her mistake, she added hot water, which produced a delicious, stringy texture that became famous
content: Raw or pasteurized cow's milk

name: Boerenkaas
fun: The flavor changes depending on the season, with summer milk producing a more floral taste compared to winter milk
content: Raw cow's milk

name: Bundz
fun: The leftover whey from making Bundz is used to create a popular, sour, and refreshing drink called żętyca (or tyca)
content: Sheep's milk in Podhale region

name: Raclette de Savoie
fun: The name comes from the French verb racler (to scrape), as shepherds scraped the melted cheese onto bread or potatoes
content: Raw or thermized cow's milk

name: Bocconcini
fun: Some varieties, like Saputo Lite Cocktail Bocconcini, offer a version with 30% less fat while maintaining the same flavor
content: Traditionally made from water buffalo milk, though commonly produced today using pasteurized cow's milk

name: Tête de Moine
fun: The name means 'monk's head' It is believed the cheese, when scraped, resembles the tonsure (bald spot) of the monks at the Abbey de Bellelay who first produced it in the 12th century
content: Unpasteurized, raw cow's milk

name: Slovenský Oštiepok
fun: Shaped like a large egg or a pine cone, with a golden brown exterior
content: Raw sheep's milk, a mixture of sheep's and cow's milk, or cow's milk

name: Queso Manchego
fun: Its distinct, traditional rind pattern mimics the braided grass molds (esparto grass) once used to drain the cheese, a pattern still required by regulatory councils
content: Milk of sheep of the Manchega breed

name: Stracchino di Crescenza
fun: often called 'tired' cheese because its name derives from stracca (Italian for 'tired'), referring to the exhaustion of cows moving between Alpine pastures and the Lombardy valley, which results in milk richer in fat
content: Italian cow's milk cheese typical of the regions of Lombardy, Tuscany, Veneto, Friuli-Venezia Giulia, and Liguria

name: Paški Sir
fun: The rocky, lunar-like landscape of Pag is inhabited by far more sheep than people
content: 100% pastuerized sheep's milk sourced exclusively from the indigenous Pag sheep breed on the Croatian island of Pag

name: Sulguni
fun: Sulguni is a 'quick' Georgian pickled cheese, often ready to eat in just one or two days, that gets its name from 'suli' (soul) and 'guli' (heart)
content: Cow and buffalo milk

name: Caciocavallo Silano
fun: The cheese is produced in a teardrop shape with a distinct neck, tied in pairs, and hung over a horizontal wooden rod ('cavallo') to mature
content: Raw or fresh cow's milk

name: Brie de Melun
fun: If aged for several months, the rind turns dark, and the cheese becomes very strong, earning the name Brie Noir
content: Cow milk that is typically unpasteurized

name: Morbier
fun: Historically, the black streak was made from real ash taken from the bottom of the cheesemaker's cooking cauldron to prevent mold or insects from damaging the curd
content: Exclusively with unpasteurised milk

name: Galotyri
fun: This tangy, yogurt-like spreadable cheese was crowned the 2023 Great Taste Supreme Champion,
content: At least 70% sheep's milk and up to 30% goat's milk

name: Slovenská Parenica
fun: Traditional Slovak steamed, smoked sheep’s milk cheese with a distinctive 'S' shape and fibrous, stringy, and elastic texture
content: Mixture of raw sheep's and cow's milk, where the content of sheep's milk must be at least 50%

name: Oscypek
fun: Historically, these cheeses were used by highlanders to pay for goods and services
content: A minimum of 60% unpasteurized sheep’s milk, with the remainder often being cow's milk

name: Kefalotyri
fun: Despite being a pillar of Greek cuisine, this popular appetizer was actually invented in Chicago, Illinois, rather than in Greece
content: Sheep milk or goat's milk (or both) in Greece and Cyprus

name: Reblochon
fun: It is a 'tax-evasion' cheese, born to avoid high taxes based on milk production, farmers would only partially milk their cows during inspection, later performing a second, secret milking ('reblocher') to produce this rich, creamy cheese.
content: Raw cow's milk

name: Taleggio
fun: Famously known for its incredibly pungent, 'stinky' smell—often compared to body odor or wet grass
content: Exclusively of pasteurized cow's milk

name: Époisses
fun: Often called 'the king of cheeses' that is so odoriferous it is rumored to be banned from public transport in France
content: Either raw (unpasteurized) or pasteurized exclusively from whole cow's milk

name: Tomme de Savoie
fun: Historically, this was a peasant cheese made from whatever milk was left after making larger, more expensive wheels like Beaufort
content: Raw, leftover skimmed cow's milk

name: Queso Payoyo
fun: The cheese is made from the milk of the Payoya goat, which is considered an endangered breed, making the consumption of the cheese a way to promote its sustainability
content: Milk of Payoya goats and Merina grazalemeña sheep

name: Tomme des Pyrénées
fun: Despite being a rustic, traditional mountain cheese, it is often noted for tasting similar to a creamier, softer version of modern Babybel
content: Cow's milk

name: Formaella Arachovas Parnassou
fun: This cheese is considered a 'gastronomic treasure' of the Arachova region, produced under strict PDO regulations since 1996, meaning true Formaella is rarely found outside this specific mountain area
content: Sheep's milk, goat's milk, or a mixture of both

name: Myzithra
fun: Actually made from the leftover whey of other cheeses like Feta
content: Pasteurized sheep's milk

name: Old Amsterdam
fun: Old Amsterdam is actually a relatively young, factory-produced cheese that matures in only 8 months—much faster than the 10–12 months traditional for old Gouda
content: Pasteurized cow's milk

name: Queijo Minas
fun: It is so culturally significant that its artisanal production, often involving small, family-run farms, is recognized as a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage
content: Cow's milk

name: Bitto
fun: One of the world's longest-aged edible cheeses, with specialized 'Bitto Storico' (or 'Storico Ribelle') wheels matured for up to 18 years, developing a intense, nutty, and crystalline texture
content: Mostly raw whole cow’s milk (from Braunvieh cows) blended with 10% to 20% raw goat’s milk

name: Saint-Marcellin
fun: It is so runny when ripe that it is typically sold in a small, protective earthenware crock to prevent it from escaping
content: Cow's milk

name: Gruyère
fun: Historically, it was developed by medieval peasants as a way to preserve milk, with the first recorded mention dating back to 1115
content: Only raw milk from cows fed with natural forage (grass in summer and hay in winter) and without any additives or ensilage

name: Tulum Peyniri
fun: Unlike modern cheeses, it is stuffed into goat or sheep hides, which are sometimes perforated to let whey drain, allowing the skin to impart a unique, earthy, and pungent flavor
content: Raw sheep's milk, though goat's milk or mixtures (including cow's milk) are common, especially in commercial varieties

name: Manouri
fun: While feta is tangy and salty, Manouri is created by adding fresh cream to the whey left over from making feta, resulting in a soft, rich, and much milder cheese
content: Goat or sheep milk that is typically pasteurized

name: Telemea de Ibăneşti
fun: The cheese was originally produced only in Romania but when the Vlach population started spreading beyond their native country, the recipe became popular in European nations like Greece, Macedonia, Bulgaria and Poland
content: Sheep's milk

name: Provola
fun: It is sometimes aged by hiding a whole lemon inside the cheese, which infuses it with a citrusy scent as it matures
content: Pasteurized milk

name: Rocamadour
fun: By the 15th century, Rocamadour's popularity was such that peasant farmers were allowed to use these small goat cheese discs to pay their taxes and land rent
content: 100% whole, raw goat’s milk

name: Saint Agur
fun: It is technically a 60% butterfat double-cream cheese, giving it a remarkably smooth, buttery texture compared to traditional blues
content: Pasteurised cow's milk

name: Kopanisti
fun: Kopanisti translates to 'beaten' or 'whipped' referring to the method where it is hand-kneaded 3-4 times during maturation to distribute the pungent microbial flora
content: Raw, whole cow’s, sheep’s, or goat’s milk, or mixtures thereof

name: Scamorza
fun: It has a surprisingly insulting name that literally translates to 'severed head' or 'beheaded' (capa mozza), referencing its unique hanging, pear-like shape. Because of this, calling someone a 'scamorza' in local Italian slang can jokingly mean they are an 'idiot' or have a weak character.
content: Cow's milk, or less commonly from milk of other species

name: Queijo de Évora
fun: It was once common practice to pay farm workers in the Évora district with this cheese instead of money
content: Merina Branca sheep's milk

name: Queijo do Pico
fun: Despite being a small island, this cheese was historically produced only for local, familial consumption
content: Cow's milk and coagulated with natural rennet

name: Queijo São Jorge
fun: The cheese has a unique, tangy, and spicy, 'bite' that many believe cannot be replicated with modern cultures
content: Pasteurized milk from the island's cows

name: Kasseri
fun: Despite being a staple of Greek cuisine, its name likely stems from a Hebrew word (kashér), and it is believed to have been invented by Jewish residents in Kırkkilise (now Kırklareli, Turkey) in the 19th centur
content: Primarily from sheep's milk, often blended with a maximum of 20% goat's milk

name: Selles-sur-Cher
fun: While it looks intimidating, the edible black layer is actually powdered vegetable charcoal (historically burnt grape vine shoots) that balances the cheese's pH, allowing mold to grow while creating a stark, beautiful contrast with the snow-white paste
content: Pasteurized goat's milk

name: Queso Zamorano
fun: Despite being a firm, hard cheese, it boasts a surprisingly complex flavor, described as having hints of nut, grass, and even white chocolate in older versions
content: Whole raw milk of Churra and Castilian sheep breeds

name: Mori no
fun: The name Mori no means 'forest' in Japanese, and it is crafted to taste like the mountain forests of Nagano where the cows graze
content: Milk of grazing Brown Swiss cows

name: Sakura
fun: Remarkably, it was the first Japanese cheese to win a gold medal at the Mountain Cheese Olympics in Switzerland, beating traditional European cheeses
content: whole, thermised organic Hokkaido cow's milk

name: Colby
fun: Colby cheese was invented in 1885 by Joseph Steinwand in Colby, Wisconsin, who created it by washing cheddar curds with cold water to reduce acidity
content: 100% all-natural Canadian cow's milk (pasteurized)
